awd_titl_txt: The Effects of Scheduling Regulation on Workers and Families
awd_abstract_narration:
The courts and legislatures have played a large role in shaping today's workplaces, for example through minimum wages, anti-discrimination policy, and workplace safety requirements. Historically, legal standards also created the current U.S. norms around scheduling, including the 8-hour workday and the weekend. But in recent years, regulation of the labor market has focused little attention on scheduling, despite the fact that the nature of work schedules has been shifting dramatically. In particular, while the earlier generation of scheduling regulation concentrated on preventing employers from extracting too much labor from workers, many of today's workers fear instead too much variability and unpredictability in work and pay. Labor advocates have raised concerns about employers shifting the risk of variable customer demand from themselves to their employees, by giving workers neither hours nor pay when demand is unexpectedly low. Such risk-shifting, recent research has shown, can harm worker health and well-being. Given the demographic changes in both family structure and the low-wage workforce, many service workers today are single parents without other adults in the household on whom to rely, meaning that this risk-shifting may harm children as well. By examining a regulation that addresses work schedule unpredictability, this project will help identify the consequences of these new legislative interventions in the employer-employee relationship. This study will evaluate whether such regulations are feasible to implement and enforce, at a key time when many jurisdictions are considering similar untested legislation.
  
The research project will evaluate a new labor law, the Fair Workweek Standard (FWS), which will go into effect January 1, 2020, in Philadelphia.  The research team will gather daily data from 1,000 low-wage workers with a young child using an innovative survey tool. Data will be collected in two waves: prior to FWS implementation (fall 2019) and post-implementation (spring 2020). The team has designed a text-message survey tool to collect detailed daily reports about work schedule changes and worker and family well-being. The sample will be balanced across those working in: (1) retail, food and hospitality firms that meet threshold local and global employment levels and are subject to regulation from the FWS and 2) otherwise similar firms below those thresholds, which are exempt from the FWS. The project will answer three key research questions: (1) What is the impact of the Philadelphia FWS on working parents' schedule unpredictability? (2) What are the effects of schedule unpredictability on the well-being of low-wage workers and their families? (3) Are there any unintended effects of the legislation on working parents' hours, earnings, and employment?

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project examined the work, health and family functioning of over 1,000 hourly service workers in Philadelphia, PA over the period 2019-2022. This project collected daily reports over the period of one month in fall 2019, two weeks in spring 2020 and one month in fall 2020, as well as point-in-time surveys in March-April, 2020, June-July, 2020, September-November, 2020, December, 2020-January, 2021, March-June 2021, June-November, 2021, and January-May, 2022.Originally focused on work schedule unpredictability and its impacts on wellbeing and designed to capture the effects of novel “Fair Workweek” regulation of work schedules, the project expanded during the COVID-19 pandemic to examine the impacts of other novel policies, including: expanded unemployment and nutrition assistance benefits, the Child Tax Credit, emergency sick leave, and remote schooling. The project also collected data on the mid-pandemic implementation of the scheduling regulations in order to understand how novel regulations are experienced during a period of employment upheaval. 


Key findings from this project include: 


  • Results demonstrate that short-notice changes to work schedules are common in hourly service work, affecting the overwhelming majority of workers over the course of a month, and that changes are disruptive to worker health and well-being. Changes to start and end times, and in particular canceled shifts, harm worker mental health; surprise shifts, by contrast, do not harm worker health but do disrupt child care arrangements, with implications for child wellbeing.

  • The onset of the COVID-19 pandemic was devastating to hourly service workers and their families, throwing many into unemployment while creating stressful working conditions for those who remained employed, disrupting schooling and child care arrangements, and causing illness. Families that experienced a greater number of these pandemic-induced hardships reported higher levels of both adult and child psychological distress.

  • In Fall 2020, child care and schooling arrangements continued to be frequently disrupted, whether in-person (sudden closures or requirements that a child quarantine) or virtual (software, hardware, and internet failures). Such disruptions led to large increases in both parent and child psychological distress.

  • Results from point-in-time surveys, which focused on policy innovations including changes in Unemployment Insurance and food assistance laws, an expansion of the Child Tax Credit, and emergency sick leave, demonstrate striking prevention of harm in populations able to benefit from novel social insurance regulation, along with racial disparities in access and therefore in impacts. In particular, respondents who were able to access Unemployment Insurance in the wake of layoff, relative to otherwise similar respondents whose applications were unsuccessful, experienced fewer material hardships and had better psychological outcomes. However, respondents of color in general, and Black and Hispanic respondents in particular, were less likely to have their applications approved and therefore did not benefit as much as White respondents from the expansions to that program.


COVID-related disruptions delayed and altered implementation of the Fair Workweek law, complicating assessment. However, we extended data collection and added new survey instruments to adapt to the new environment. Data were collected through summer 2022 and analyses are ongoing.
